projects.name: Bike Finder
projects.description:
You will conceive and prototype an interface for finding and selecting a bicycle to purchase from on online store.

From one perspective, this is very straightforward: we've all used online stores to find and buy things. From another perspective, you'll discover a multitude of decisions you must make as a designer in order to accomplish the task. Among other things, you'll need to ask:

  • Who are my stakeholders?
  • What are they trying to accomplish?
  • What do they already know?
  • What do they need to know?
  • What do they care about?
  • What constitutes success?

This project is not about inventing something new, or making something beautiful. Rather, it is about recognizing and applying what's appropriate, and making something that works well for the people using it. The most successful solutions will likely be largely transparent to the user's conscious mind.

The final product of the project will be a clickable prototype that allows you to demonstrate your solution. It will not include the check-out process, nor parts of the site unrelated to the process of selecting a bicycle. It will not include any 'real' programming, or dynamic data. For instance, you should not attempt to make a 'search' feature actually search. It will include everything necessary to clearly convey how the interface will work. Therefore, a search button should take us to a view that looks like search results.

deliverables.name: Research: UI Conventions
deliverables.description: You probably have plenty of experience as an online shopper, and the user-interface conventions used by online stores probably feel very familiar to you. But have you ever taken the time to identify them? Let's do some shopping for various items, with an eye focused on UI. We'll make some observations and see what patterns emerge.
deliverables.instructions:
With a partner, buy four different items, each at a different online store. (Don't check out, just get as far as the 'Add to Cart' button.) Before you start, pre-select items that are specific, that have some options (size, color, horse-power, capacity, etc.), and that represent a variety of needs and price-points. (An example list: a dark grey cable-knit sweater, a riding lawn mower, a two-line high-performance kite, a mid-range gaming laptop.) Make sure at least two items come from 'niche' stores, not big-box retailers. For each store and item, document the following:

  • What UI elements did I see and/or interact with while finding, comparing, selecting, and configuring the specific product?
  • Have I seen this UI element before in other contexts?
  • Did I know what this element would do before I interacted with it? Why?
  • What general problem is this element designed to handle?
  • Why was it used in this context? Is it successful?

Discuss with your partner as you go. Perhaps take turns being shopper and observer. Together, see if you can put names to things: 'Query field. Checkbox. Drop-down selector. Results list.' Don't limit yourself to just clickable things, also note the contextual affordances that help you understand what's happening: titles, labels, icons, etc. Make particular note of any confusion/mistakes/wrong turns you make. What misdirected you?

When you are done, summarize your findings:

  • What elements or patterns seem universal?
  • Did I see anything that felt different or unusual?
  • What elements or patterns were specific to the store or product?
  • Were there any patterns or techniques that made one store stand out? Could the other stores have applied that technique successfully?
  • Finally, how did you feel when interacting with these sites? When were you happiest/most comfortable? When were you disrupted/confused/bothered?

Feel free to trade/combine observation notes with your partner, but write your own concluding summaries. Structure your observations, notes, and summaries as an HTML document, then upload via Github, at the path shown below.

deliverables.name: Product Knowledge
deliverables.description:
If we're going to sell bikes, we need to know about them and how people use them. So let's do some product and user research. Some things we might care about:

  • The physical product (materials, options, specifications)
  • Product variations (sizes, types and purposes, quality range, performance range, price range, brands)
  • Bike users (demographics, purpose, frequency of use, motivators)
  • The buying experience (Where bikes are sold, by whom, purchase considerations)

Sources for this information might include:

  • Your own experience/knowledge
  • Your friends/peers experience/knowledge
  • Online stores
  • Local bike shops
  • Online groups (clubs, forums, social media)
  • Other online buyer's guides

Finally, just like you did in your general UI research, 'buy' a bike at a few different online retailers. For now, focus on what YOU would want if you were actually buying a bike for yourself today. What would you use it for? What features do you care about? How will you know if it fits you? How will you select a brand and price point?
deliverables.instructions: Educate yourself about bikes and bike users, considering the factors and sources noted above. Challenge yourself to push past what you already know – find some suprises. Create an HTML document that lists the sources you used and briefly describes how you used them. Then summarize and analyze. What big questions will a buyer will be faced with? What priorities might they have? What did you run into that you didn't understand, and now you do?

deliverables.name: User Traits
deliverables.description: Define and list of user traits with the class.
deliverables.instructions: Join the Google document referenced below, and brainstorm traits and possible trait expressions with your classmates.

deliverables.name: Personas
deliverables.description: Define and document a persona with your group.
deliverables.instructions: With your group, copy the persona template we've created together, and flesh out your assigned persona. Be sure to include the elements of a persona as we defined them in class. This is not just about collecting words together – it is about imagining a person, empathizing with them, and making them feel human. It requires imagination and writing skill to fill in the gaps so the rest of us will understand who this person is! Create/edit the persona in the Google Doc referenced below.

references.name: QuickCycle Persona 1 - Parent and child | Big Kim and Little Kim
references.description: Group 1 will assemble this persona.

references.name: QuickCycle Persona 2 - Teen commuter | Michael Stevens
references.description: Group 2 will assemble this persona.

references.name: QuickCycle Persona 3 - Extreme BMXer | Tammy Osprey
references.description: Group 3 will assemble this persona.

references.name: QuickCycle Persona 4 - Middle-aged transporter | Maxine
references.description: Group 4 will assemble this persona.

references.name: QuickCycle Persona 5 - Fitness and family senior | Tom Jenkins
references.description: Group 5 will assemble this persona.

deliverables.name: User Stories
deliverables.description: Break into groups, one for each persona. Inhabit the persona – put yourself in this person’s shoes, envision how they might approach the task of purchasing a bicycle online. Break the process down into discrete parts. At each step, what are they doing? Why? What result will they get? What will they think? What will they do next?
deliverables.instructions:
Write every user story you imagine this persona would have. Follow the user story pattern: "As <a persona or role>, I want <to perform this action action> so that <I can accomplish this goal>." Add your user stories to our user story spreadsheet.

Once we've collected user stories, we need to analyze them. We will try a few approaches to grouping, refining, and scoring in order to tease out insights.

references.name: QuickCycle User Stories
references.description: We will manage user stories in this spreadsheet.

deliverables.name: User Story Analysis
deliverables.description: How do you make sense of all the user stories? How will you group, refine, and score them?
deliverables.instructions:
Make your own personal copy of the analysis document started by your group. Apply a scoring algorithm of some kind, or use whatever methods you prefer to identify which stories you MUST address, which you would LIKE to address, and which you can probably dismiss.

upload an HTML file that links to your personal google sheet. (If you don't know how to do this yet, send me a link to the google sheet via slack.)

deliverables.name: Feature Ideation
deliverables.description: Using ALL of the personas and user-stories we've collective written as reference, create a document that organizes your ideas about what solutions you propose to use.
deliverables.instructions:
1. Read through the user-stories gathered in our previous deliverable. If you choose, make your own copy of the personas and user-stories, and consolidate/organize further than we have in class.
  2. Identify possible UI solutions to address the stories. Not necessarily 1-for-1, just let the stories suggest ideas for components. A menu. A big photo. A search bar. An expanding drawer. Sometimes a single component such as a checkbox is enough. Sometimes you may end up with a set of components that work together, such as a search-field, search button, and results list. Keep an eye out for solutions that address more than one story/need, or that can be enhanced to address additional needs. For instance, a basic search bar might be enhanced with an 'auto-suggest' feature.
  3. Organize your solutions into pages, or views. What views need to exist? What responsibilities does each view have?
  4. Format your decisions in a document (or set of documents) that conveys as much as possible about your decisions, with as little effort as possible. The idea is to communicate a plan that's both easy to follow, and easy to change.

deliverables.name: Low-Fidelity Wireframes
deliverables.description: Create low-fidelity wireframes that visualize the features you've identified.
deliverables.instructions:
Create wireframes with whatever tool you choose, but stay low-fidelity. Don't waste time making it pretty: make it CLEAR. At the same time, do not over-simplify in terms of information. Provide enough information so we can understand what's happening. If a product in the list includes a title or a price, show those things.

Don't be satisfied with your first run at it... it's probably incomplete. Expect to iterate. Practice 'using' your wireframes with our personas. Can you complete the user-stories for each persona?

references.name: Google Slides: Session 6
references.description: Abe's recommendations for making useful low-fidelity wireframes.

deliverables.name: Low-Fidelity Wireframes - Testing
deliverables.description:
In class we will break into pairs and test each others' wireframes against randomly-selected user-stories.

As the TESTER, you will select a persona and user-story, and describe what you are seeing/thinking as you attempt to complete the objective posed by that story. You will not provide evaluative feedback, you will just describe what you are doing as you do it.

As the OBSERVER, you will observe and take notes. You will not describe your intent, explain what anything represents, provide any hints, etc. You will ONLY, if asked, describe the objective result of an action: e.g: 'Since you clicked on that button, you would now see the view represented in the second image.'

Our objective is not to defend choices as the UX designer, nor evaluate them as the tester. Rather, we are attempting to provide/observe an unbiased, uninfluenced reaction to your wireframe, both good and bad.

The test will end when the tester either a) reports they have completed the objective, or b) reports they are unable to complete the objective. After the test is complete, you may converse briefly to ask questions or clarify misunderstandings.

We'll remain in pairs for 20 minutes, 10 minutes for each wireframe. Complete as many user-stories as you are able in that time. We'll then mix up our groups and test again, and again, for a total of three pairings.
deliverables.instructions: Post an html document with your observations and feedback notes (or which links to same). Include your analysis of the raw findings: what are the takeaways for you?

deliverables.name: Mid-Fidelity Wireframes - Revisions
deliverables.description: Revise your wireframe based on your test results. Add details, clean up structure, consider building digitally. Aim to have as complete a 'blueprint' as possible without getting into style.
deliverables.instructions: Make sure to COPY your wireframe then make changes to the copy, so the original wireframe remains untouched, and we can compare the two. As before, post the revised wireframe.

deliverables.name: Content Collection
deliverables.description: Collect the assets you will likely need for mockups. Bike product images, lifestyle and/or category images, bike info (descriptions, names, prices, specs, etc.), lists of things like brands/manufacturers. Draft any copy you think you'll need: calls to action, nav labels, messaging for newbies, etc.
deliverables.instructions: Embed all of these assets in an html document. Don't use Word, or google docs, or a PDF. Create a simple HTML document from which you can copy/paste text, image URLs, anything and everything you think you'll need for assets.

references.name: QuickCycle Logo
references.description: Logo art for you to use

deliverables.name: Visual Mockups
deliverables.description: Create mockups that present the decisions you made in wireframing, along with base style choices that make it presentation friendly.
deliverables.instructions:
After you're certain your wireframes represent a complete set of functional decisions, it's time to create a high-fidelity visual mockup that is client-facing. Your aim is to present your UI solutions in a way that provides not only clear functional direction, but clear style direction. Use the logo referenced below. Don't worry about any elements of the site and page not related to actually finding a bike. Better to leave those very loosely defined, with a clear distinction between what is and is not 'fully-realized.' For instance, you might 'ghost' anything that is not part of the bike-finding experience. Focus on hierarchy, legibility, and clarity. Aim for your UI elements to be the unobtrusive frame in which the content is displayed.

This mockup will become a clickable prototype in next steps, but for now, just make a series of pages that 'loop' when clicked: clicking anywhere on home takes me to list, anywhere on list takes me to detail, anywhere on detail takes me back to home. You can accomplish this either with a prototyping tool (XD, Figma, etc), or with images in HTML documents linked together with simple <a> tags.

references.name: QuickCycle Logo
references.description: Logo art for you to use

references.name: Questions sparked by Abe's review of visual mockups
references.description: We'll discuss these in class, but please also consider them for your design specifically.

references.name: Signup sheet for meeting with Abe
references.description: Add your name to this doc if you'd like to meet with me today.

deliverables.name: Clickable Prototypes
deliverables.description: Create presentation-ready prototypes with enough interactive functionality to demonstrate possible paths through the bike-finding process.
deliverables.instructions:
When your high-fidelity mockups are ready, add interactivity so we can walk through them in a plausible way. Don't worry about simulating every possible user interaction – focus on those interactions that guide us through the 'typical' experience and that point out key features, such as clicking a search bar and getting to the search results view, or clicking a thumbnail to get to a bike detail view.

You may also consider adding interaction to show key transient UI interactions such as a menu flyout, or expanded filter control.

Make sure your prototype is self-sufficient. In other words, make sure the rest of us can click through your prototype successfully without your input or explanation.

deliverables.name: Prototypes - Testing
deliverables.description: As we did with wireframes, pair up in class to test each other's prototypes. Spend part of your time testing as we did before (user-story driven, no discussion, just observing what the tester does), then spend a little soliciting/providing feedback more traditionally. As before, we'll spend 20 minutes per pairing, and 3 pairings, for a total of about an hour.
deliverables.instructions: Post an html document with your observations and feedback notes (or which links to same). Include a brief analysis of the raw findings: what are the takeaways for you?

deliverables.name: Final Presentation-Ready Prototype
deliverables.description: We're done making, now it's time to present. Prepare to give a short (5 min or less) walk-through of your prototype, pointing out key features and design choices. (Hint: well-applied conventions are a good design choices, don't short-change them!) Your presentation should address both functionality and style rationale. We'll have a guest reviewer on Wednesday to watch your presentations and provide feedback.
deliverables.instructions: Post a link to your final presentation-ready Figma or XD file.

projects.name: Soccer League Application
projects.description:
A user's role in an application often controls their permissions – what they are allowed to see and do within the application. For instance: what a faculty member can see and do within Canvas is different than what a student can see and do.

Our second project this semester will provide an opportunity to explore how roles affect and inspire the behavior and presentation of an application. We will collaboratively plan and prototype an application for a youth soccer league. This application will have three different roles: players (and parents), coaches, and league administrators. Each role will likely have both distinct and overlapping objectives, features, and permissions.

Unlike the bike-finder, this project has a much broader landscape of opportunities for feature ideas and implementations. While we'll still concern ourselves with UI conventions and useful design patterns, we will also put more attention on innovation and creative problem solving.

We will divide the class into collaborative groups of three for this project. Each individual in a group will assume responsibility for a single user role. Put plainly, one of you will focus on player/parent needs perspectives, and ultimately design and implement features for that role. Another will focus on coach needs and perspectives, and the third will focus on the league administrator role. You woll work together with your groupmates to understand, ideate, plan, and coordinate responsibilities for features that 'cross' roles. You will work more independently on those aspects of the application that are specific to your role. You will also collaborate 'across groups' with your peers in other groups that share a role focus (e.g.: all the coach-oriented students meet to share ideas and insights).

The final deliverable for this project will again be a clickable prototype, but this time one which you've assembled with two other people.

deliverables.name: Data Model
deliverables.description: Collaborate with your group to define entities and properties for your application.
deliverables.instructions: Use the links below to access the shared document for your group.

deliverables.name: Interview Preparation
deliverables.description: As we discussed in class, we want go into interviews with a base level of knowledge about soccer, league sports, and the roles involved in both. What questions would you ask of people who fill those roles? How can you get them to share stories, insights, needs and perspectives? What topics do you want to make sure you cover with them? What research will you do ahead of time to prepare yourself?
deliverables.instructions: Create a google doc in which you collect your plans and preparation for interviews. Upload an HTML document that links to your google doc (similar to the way you posted links to your figma files for the bike finder).

projects.name: Configurator
projects.description:
If you've ordered Pizza online, you know what a 'configurator' is — the interface by which you step through the various choices/options available to 'customize' something you want to describe. Thin-crust or deep dish, light cheese or heavy, Which meats? Which veggies?

In this project, you will design a configurator interface — but the object being configured is up to you. Could be pizza if you like, but could also be something like an airline ticket. The choice is yours... within some parameters:

  • The item being configured must have a finite set of pre-defined options that can be clearly articulated and easily understood.
  • Completion of the user-experience should be possible in no more than 3–5 steps.
  • The item must be commonly understood, requiring only a minimum of 'education' in order to configure.
  • Abe must approve it. :)

This project does not have a defined final deliverable, other than to say the finished product of your work should easily allow anybody to simulate the configuration process. You may choose to actually build and program the configurator in html/css/js, you may choose to build a clickable prototype, you may choose to only provide a series of mockups. You should, however, play to your strengths. Decide on a topic and a final deliverable that showcases your abilities, and maximizes the value of the time you spend.

What will I be looking for? Research. Clarity of problem/purpose. An understanding of your audience. Ease of use. Evidence of a strong work ethic. A self-sufficient end-product. Reasoned UX choices. Transparently usable and accessible UI. Ultimately, that it shows well!

deliverables.name: Proposal
deliverables.description:
Write a proposal indicating the object or experience you intend to configure and how it is configurable. Explain your current understanding of the need, then describe how you intend to research, understand, and document the users' needs. Describe the kind of final deliverable you expect to create, and how that deliverable plays to your strengths. Enumerate what you expect to be able to show as progress in each class session between today and the final day of class.

Think of this proposal itself as a reference document you are creating. It describes the need, the scope of your intentions, and your plan for implementation. In reality it will be a reference for you and me, but treat it like a self-sufficient document: if you were to hand it to somebody without explanation or context, they should be able to understand what you plan to do, why, and how.

Finally, consider what you will need to include in this document in order to make it be a useful reference as we progress through the project.
deliverables.instructions: Upload your proposal as a PDF. We will refer to it as we check progress through this project. I don't expect you to meet every goal you set perfectly, but I will expect you to meet me each week with either a met objective, or a revised plan.

deliverables.name: Flow Chart and/or Options Lists
deliverables.description: Create a reference document that walks us through the specific configuration options of your object 'on paper'.
deliverables.instructions: The document may be visual or textual, but should clearly communicate what the configuration steps are, and what options are available at each step. Be specific. It is not sufficient to use placeholder values. Upload the document as HTML. If you build a visual flowchart, embed it as an image.

references.name: Course Evaluation
references.description: Your feedback is extremely helpful to me, and I greatly appreciate it! Answers are anonymous, and I don't see any feedback until after I've submitted your grades.
